title: Mum spent last money in her account launching jewellery line now making millions
text:
Get the biggest money stories by email Subscribe Thank you for subscribing We have more newsletters Show me See our privacy notice Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email

It isn’t easy to stay positive when you’ve just lost a loved one.

But the loss of her father ‒ and the search for a way to stay positive - played a part in Stephanie Dunleavy launching a range of jewellery that reinforces positive messages that is now being worn by famous faces across the globe.

Stephanie was pregnant with her first child, and living with her husband's mum, when the range was launched - but they put their "full faith" behind the jewellery collection along with every penny they had.

And what began as a blog has now turned into a business that’s set to turnover more than a million pounds.

The last £1,000

Stephanie and husband Jasper wanted to make changes to their life, in order to adopt a more positive mindset, following the passing of her father.

Stephanie says she was at “an all-time low” but the pair introduced “mindfulness, gratitude and affirmations to our daily habits”.

After seeing how quickly their lives seemed to change once they changed their perspective, they then became passionate about helping others to do the same.

This started with the Soul Analyse blog and social media profile, which was set up to dish out positive reminders on a daily basis.

But then the couple came up with the idea of a jewellery collection that would do much the same thing, with items engraved with positive messages beginning with the words ‘I am’, such as ‘I am capable’, ‘I am worthy’ and ‘I am me’.

Circumstances weren’t exactly ideal for the pair though, as they were living with Jasper’s mum and Stephanie was five months pregnant with their first child.

Stephanie said: “We had just £1,000 in the bank and decided to put our full faith into the jewellery collection.

"It was an exciting time for us but also extremely difficult; we weren't able to buy a single item for our baby and relied heavily on hand-me-downs from family and friends.”

Multi-tasking with the baby

Things started slowly, particularly once the baby arrived, but Stephanie emphasises they did not lose faith.

“In those early days our passion really kept us going and we found a way to juggle parent/work life.

"There were many times where I was feeding the baby with one hand, balancing my laptop on my lap and taking notes with the other hand.”

Spreading the word

Stephanie says that the biggest challenge at this point was simply spreading the word, as any funds they had were devoted to the actual jewellery, so there was nothing to pay for any marketing.

However, winning the support of people in the public eye ‒ like Gok Wan ‒ helped them to fill that gap.

“Instagram endorsements really helped us in those early days. We relied on celebrities and TV stars, and well-known influencers from America.

"We had started getting noticed by the press, and were featured in well-read magazines, like Elle.”

The firm also tapped into the power of social media, building up a community of around 50,000 followers who Stephanie said “appreciated what we stood for” and helped get the word out there about the jewellery line.

She added: “We have a lot to thank them for - they have stayed loyal to us throughout and kept us going during the hard times.”

On track

Things look rather different today, with the jewellery range now available from a host of well known outlets.

These include the likes of Asos Marketplace and SilkFred, while the items are also sold by plenty of independent stores, not just in the UK but overseas as well.

Stephanie said that while there are still hard times that come with running the business, such as on cash flow, the couple are “certainly on track”, with turnover forecast at more than £1million for next year.

“It has been disgustingly hard getting here - it has quite literally taken blood, sweat and tears. Even when I was diagnosed with breast cancer last year, we kept it together and we never let go of our dream of making something of this.

"Thankfully, I am better now and I know nothing can stop us because, above everything, we've got passion that keeps us going.

As for would-be entrepreneurs who want to follow their own dreams, Stephanie argued that it is better to act now, and think later.

“The mind is very powerful and we can talk ourselves out of the best ideas. Don't think too much about the obstacles because it will feel overwhelming and you won't even start.

"Just take that first leap of faith and you will find a way as long as you have passion in your idea. When the chips are down and you feel like quitting, passion will keep you going.”
description: The I Am range from Soul Analyse has gone on to win fans across the world including Gok Wan and Rebekah Vardy - but it was a massive risk when new mum Stephanie Dunleavy and her husband launched it
